justification: The study by Dupont et al. (2022) used a task where participants dragged numbered circles in sequence to the bottom of a screen, with specific colors indicating the need to set external reminders for certain items. This task measures how participants choose between holding information in short-term memory and offloading it to the external environment.

The paper simulates the decision-making processes behind cognitive offloading using a Monte Carlo reinforcement learning model. This model balances rewards associated with remembering items against the costs of internal memory and offloading strategies, illustrating value-based decision making.

Accuracy for remembering high- and low-value items when offloading is allowed versus when it's not is measured in experimental conditions. These tests help assess the impact of cognitive offloading on memory performance.

measured_by: Accuracy reduction with increasing memory load
justification: Accuracy measures when storing different numbers of items (e.g., 3 vs. 6) in internal memory demonstrate the opportunity cost associated with using limited memory capacity. This is used to simulate the benefits of offloading information externally.

measured_by: Variation in offloading rate with physical effort
justification: The study by Chiu and Gilbert (2023) manipulated the physical effort required to set reminders, showing how changes in effort sensitivity influence the offloading rate of participants.

Studies have shown a negative correlation between internal memory ability and offloading rate, indicating that individuals with poorer memory ability are more likely to offload information, which can be measured through memory capacity assessments.
